image.altText: A man in a suit stands to speak to parliament.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's deputy premier, Michael Ferguson, resigns as infrastructure minister over the bungled rollout of the new Spirit of Tasmania vessels.

title.children: Minister Michael Ferguson resigns over Spirit of Tasmania port debacle

image.altText: A sign showing the TasNetworks logo on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: The head of Tasmania's state-owned utility company, TasNetworks, says he will "have it out" with the electrical union at the Fair Work Commission after the union ignored an order to return to work.

title.children: TasNetworks to take union to Fair Work over outages as farmers forced to find generators

image.altText: Woman holding a young toddler.

props.synopsis: Months after Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom was killed in an Israeli air strike, her brother Mal sits down with 7.30 to discuss the missing pieces of the puzzle the Israeli government still has not shared.

title.children: Inside the hour of misery that changed the lives of the Frankcom family

image.altText: Yellow billboard next to busy street

props.synopsis: The Jacqui Lambie Network's implosion in Tasmania follows a growing list of Australian personality parties that have quickly encountered turbulence.

title.children: Does the Lambie implosion show that 'personality politics' is doomed to fail?

image.altText: A man in a blue suit and red tie and a woman in a camel-coloured suit and white shirt

props.synopsis: Americans remain deeply polarised over their choice between Kamala Harris or Donald Trump in November's presidential election. In Australia, a new survey suggests one candidate has overwhelming support.

title.children: Harris or Trump? If Australians were voting, the result would be a landslide

image.altText: John Setka sitting behind a number of microphones at a Melbourne media conference.

props.synopsis: Mr Setka claims former Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke agreed to forgo appointing administrators to the CFMEU in exchange for the union boss's resignation.

title.children: PM says former union boss's claim he was left 'trembling' after elevator conversation is 'nonsense'

image.altText: Police tape stretched over a suburban road. A police paddy wagon and van are parked nearby.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating after 29-year-old underworld figure Tarek Ayoub was shot and killed in the car park of a Parramatta unit complex on Monday morning. Mr Ayoub, who was known in underworld circles as the "Angel of Death", was visiting an associate, according to police.

title.children: 'Lived by the sword and died by the sword': Sydney underworld figure killed in execution-style murder

image.altText: A digital board with multiple rows reading "cancelled".

props.synopsis: A long-awaited blueprint for the aviation sector will be handed down today, including a promise to establish a charter of rights for customers to seek cash refunds when their flights are cancelled or unreasonably delayed.

title.children: Australians will be able to get cash refunds for delayed and cancelled flights under government crackdown

image.altText: A group of men in red berets stand in a huddle

props.synopsis: Hezbollah and Israel's war is escalating. Four Corners travelled to Lebanon's Hezbollah heartland and found a group determined to hit back.

title.children: As war in the Middle East deepens, a decades-long fight becomes a new front line

props.synopsis: A senator is calling for the government to end its long-standing relationship with South Korea's Eastern Social Welfare Society after a Background Briefing investigation revealed the agency falsified documents in historical adoption cases, dating back to the 1980s.

title.children: 'A demand for orphans': Senator calls for end to Korean adoptions

image.altText: Qld heat Southbank sunbathers August 25

props.synopsis: It may be the last week of winter but temperatures are rising across Australia — and in several places, winter heat records have already been broken.

title.children: 'No reprieve in sight' to unseasonably hot weather after new winter records set

image.altText: A close up of a man with blonde hair smiling with his dog on a porch.

props.synopsis: The right to disconnect means you can reasonably refuse to be contacted outside of work hours. For people tied to the 'digital leash' of phones and email this marks a substantial boost in their right to break free.

title.children: You have the right to disconnect from work after hours from today. But what does that mean in practice?

image.altText: Hawthorn v Western Bulldogs

props.synopsis: The Hawks will play their first Friday night game in two years, after the AFL confirmed the week one schedule for the 2024 finals series.

title.children: AFL releases finals fixture as league heavyweights get their first Friday night clash in two years

image.altText: A billboard shows a smiling woman in colourful dress, and welcomes people to the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum.

props.synopsis: Pacific leaders are once again preparing for the Pacific Island Forum, the biggest meeting of the year, where they will gather and discuss some of the most pressing and complex issues facing the region.

title.children: In Tonga's sprawling archipelago, a meeting of Pacific leaders could reshape the region

image.altText: Woman with black dress and long wavy hair leans forward

props.synopsis: Michelle Brasier was told she had a 97 per cent chance of getting cancer. She chose to laugh about it.

title.children: If you could find out whether you were going to die young, would you?

image.altText: A man wearing a turban and pale red shirt holds a woman with a black shirt and black hair with her back to the camera

props.synopsis: Pawanjeet Heir was treated like a slave as she pursued the requirements for permanent residency in Australia. Her husband says she has been punished for speaking up.

title.children: Pawanjeet Heir's boss was running a migration scam. Speaking up put her visa at risk

image.altText: Maggie Beer

props.synopsis: In a statement on social media on Sunday night, her family said she fell at home, sustaining minor bone fractures and related injuries.

title.children: Australian food icon Maggie Beer injured after fall at home

image.altText: A man with grey hair and beard leans over bushfire bunker built into ground

props.synopsis: An Adelaide Hills father installed a six-person bushfire bunker at his property after the 2019 Cudlee Creek bushfire, without first seeking planning approvals — now, the council have issued a removal notice — a decision which he is appealing.

title.children: Daniel Katz installed a 'last resort' bunker after fleeing a bushfire, but he's been told to remove it

image.altText: two men hugging, while one carries his daughter on his hip

props.synopsis: The NT polls have closed and the results show a resounding victory for the Country Liberal Party, but there's also been some interesting swings to the Greens and independents. Here's how each electorate voted.

title.children: Breaking down the NT election outcome: How the results fell in every seat across the territory

image.altText: A police officer stands on a highway. Behind him there is a number of items scattered on the roads.

props.synopsis: The woman in her 40s remains in a serious but stable condition in hospital. A man in a domestic relationship with her, who suffered self-inflicted wounds, is also in a serious but stable condition.

title.children: 'Bloody brave' bystanders who protected woman being stabbed in car 'saved her life'

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The ASX200 has opened higher, with insurer NIB posting a 67 per cent increase in profit. It comes after US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments that it was time to start cutting rates lifted global markets on Friday. Follow the day's events on the live markets blog.

title.children: NIB profit up 67pc as ASX opens higher following US Reserve chair comments

image.altText: Selfie portrait of a bearded man in helmet and bullet-proof vest

props.synopsis: A British safety adviser working with a team of journalists is dead after a Russian missile struck a hotel in the Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk.

title.children: Reuters safety adviser killed and two journalists injured in strike on Ukrainian hotel

image.altText: A dingo lunges forward, crouching in a hunting or playful pose, its mouth open.

props.synopsis: With nine out the 16 "high-risk" dingo attacks this year involving children, the Fraser Coast mayor says the island is not an appropriate holiday destination for families with young kids.

title.children: Dingo attacks prompt call for kids to be banned from unfenced camping on K'gari

image.altText: Women with a car

props.synopsis: Road safety researchers want maximum speed limits in built-up areas cut, saying it has saved lives overseas.

title.children: Push to reduce speed limits in built-up areas from 50kph to as low as 30kph

props.synopsis: Canberra is grappling with the stubbornly high cost of housing, and many of the factors are out of the government's control — but it can control the types of properties added to the city's supply to cater for our growing population.

title.children: More people are living in the bush capital, but how well can they afford it?

image.altText: A 17th-century classical painting, showing a woman, arms outstretched, and a mostly naked man lying in front of her.

props.synopsis: When conservators at the National Gallery of Victoria X-rayed a 17th-century artwork, they discovered a strange swirl in the right-hand corner. A little investigation ultimately revealed a hidden painting.

title.children: An Australian gallery acquired this painting in the 50s. They only recently discovered its secret

image.altText: A police officer is kneeling and shaking the hand of his pet dog, who has a white-cream coat and has a dingo appearance.

props.synopsis: Financial benefits and more community involvement are helping the NSW Police Force fill positions in some of the state's most far-flung and high-crime communities.

title.children: Remote police posting a 'no-brainer' for officers looking to escape the cost and grind of city living

image.altText: Oasis mebers during a press op in Hong Kong 2006

props.synopsis: The brothers behind one of the biggest bands of the nineties have hinted they don't look back in anger and a reunion is on the cards.

title.children: Cryptic social media posts by Liam and Noel Gallagher spark rumours Oasis could reunite

image.altText: Rhiannon Clarke, WAIS athlete and paralympian, poses in the WAIS indoor running track

props.synopsis: Rhiannon Clarke is a two-time Commonwealth Games medallist, a three-time World Championship medallist and now a dual Paralympian, but that's not how she measures her greatest success.

title.children: Rhiannon Clarke is chasing gold in Paris, but her greatest success won't be found on the track

image.altText: A white satellite dish rises behind a chain-link fence.

props.synopsis: Residents and community leaders in the town of Exmouth welcome defence investment for the region but housing and water shortages remain a concern.

title.children: Calls for transparency as US military prepares for expansion in north-west Australia

image.altText: Grey-haired man with glasses smiling in backyard

props.synopsis: While some growing high-density locations are being applauded for incorporating open space with community facilities and transport, others are criticised as "dormitory suburbs" lacking in life.

title.children: For David and his family, swapping a suburban home for a city apartment has been 'mostly positive'

image.altText: A man stands in front of a flower bed in full bloom.

props.synopsis: Flowers planted for Canberra's Floriade festival are blooming weeks ahead of schedule due to warmer weather, while commercial horticulturalists are having to adapt their planting to meet the changing seasons.

title.children: No, it's not your imagination. Spring has arrived weeks earlier and gardeners are having to adapt
